nl.fw.yapool.sql

Class DbConn

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.fw.yapool.sql.DbConn

  • public class DbConn
extends Object
    A helper class that makes it easy to fire a query, get results and cleanup. A typical usage scenario is the following (see also the test-classes): 
     DbConn c = new DbConn(myPool);
 try {
        c.setNQuery("select id from t where name like @name");
        c.nps.setString("name", "searchValue");
        c.executeQuery();
        ... process results with c.rs ...
 } catch (Exception e) {
   ... handle error ...
 } finally { 
        c.close(); 
 }
    Author:
    frederikw

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static org.slf4j.Logger closeLogger
      Logger used to log a warning when a close method encounters an error.
      Connection conn
      An actual database connection, provided by implementation or set when getConnection() is called.
      SqlFactory connFactory
      Connection factory to get and close a connection.
      NamedParameterStatement nps
      A named prepared statement, set when setNQuery(String) is called.
      SqlPool pool
      Database pool to acquire and release a connection.
      PreparedStatement ps
      A prepared statement, set when setQuery(String) is called.
      IQueryCache qc
      Query cache to use with database pool (cached statements are not closed by this class).
      ResultSet rs
      A resultset, used as placeholder for the query results of a query.
      Statement st
      A (non-cached) statement, set when setStatement() is called.

      • closeLogger

        public static org.slf4j.Logger closeLogger

      • pool

        public SqlPool pool
        Database pool to acquire and release a connection.

      • qc

        public IQueryCache qc
        Query cache to use with database pool (cached statements are not closed by this class). Note that a query cache for statements with auto-generated keys will throw an SQLException.

      • connFactory

        public SqlFactory connFactory
        Connection factory to get and close a connection. Used when pool is null.

        An actual database connection, provided by implementation or set when getConnection() is called.

    • Method Detail

      • getConnection

        public Connection getConnection()
        Acquires a connection from the pool or connFactory, but only when conn is null. Sets conn to the new connection.

      • setStatement

        public Statement setStatement()
                       throws SQLException
        Sets st, closes previous query and gets a connection if needed.
        See also execute(String).
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • setQuery

        public PreparedStatement setQuery(String query)
                           throws SQLException
        Calls setQuery(String, int) with autoGeneratedKeys ignored.
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • setQuery

        public PreparedStatement setQuery(String query,
                         int autoGeneratedKeys)
                           throws SQLException
        Sets ps with the given query. Closes previous query and gets a connection if needed.
        If autoGeneratedKeys is -1, it is ignored, else if autoGeneratedKeys equals java.sql.Statement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS for example, generated keys are returned in the resultset (how generated keys are returned depends on the type of database, e.g. mysql will return a column with the name "GENERATED_KEY").
        Throws:
        SQLException - if qc if set and RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS is passed, a "not supported" exception is thrown. In this case, configure the query cache to recognize which statements generate keys (see for example SimpleQueryBuilder.addGeneratesKeys(String, boolean).

      • setStatement

        protected Statement setStatement(String query,
                     int autoGeneratedKeys)
                          throws SQLException
        Sets st if query is null, else sets ps. Closes previous query and gets a connection if needed.
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • setNQuery

        public NamedParameterStatement setNQuery(String query)
                                  throws SQLException
        Calls setNQuery(String, int) with autoGeneratedKeys ignored.
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • setNQuery

        public NamedParameterStatement setNQuery(String query,
                                int autoGeneratedKeys)
                                  throws SQLException
        Same as setQuery(String, int), but this time for a named query (sets nps instead of ps).
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • execute

        public int execute(String query)
            throws SQLException
        Execute st statement with given query.
        Calls setStatement() if needed, never uses qc.
        Returns:
        update count or -1 if there is no result or when a result-set is available and set to rs .
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • executeQuery

        public ResultSet executeQuery()
                       throws SQLException
        Executes a query set in ps or nps.
        Returns:
        the resultset from the query, also set in rs
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • executeUpdate

        public int executeUpdate()
                  throws SQLException
        Executes an update query set in ps or nps and sets any generated keys in rs (which will be empty if there are no auto-generated keys).
        Returns:
        number of records updated
        Throws:
        SQLException

      • closeQuery

        public void closeQuery()
        Closes rs and st if set. Only closes ps and/or nps if they are not cached (qc is not set). Does not release or close the database connection. Uses the closeLogger to log errors as warnings.
        Sets rs, st, ps and nps to null so that subsequent calls to this method or close() have no effect.
        This is required in for example Tomcat, see for example the "Random Connection Closed Exceptions" problem described at http://yzb.hit.edu.cn/docs/printer/jndi-datasource-examples-howto.html#Common%20Problems

      • rollbackAndClose

        public void rollbackAndClose()
        Rolls back the transaction if a connection is open and calls close().

      • rollbackAndClose

        public void rollbackAndClose(Throwable t)
        Rolls back the transaction if a connection is open and calls close().
        Parameters:
        t - if not null, this method will always throw a runtime exception after rollback and close.

      • rethrowRuntime

        public static void rethrowRuntime(Throwable t)
        Throws a runtime-exception if given exception is not null.
        Parameters:
        t - if an instance of a runtime-exception, throws the runtime-exception, else throws a runtime-exception with information copied from checked exception.

      • close

        public void close()
        Calls closeQuery() and, if there is a pool, releases the database connection or closes the database connection.

      • close

        public static void close(Statement s)
        Closes a statement (checks for null-value), logs any error as warning using closeLogger.

        public static void close(NamedParameterStatement s)
        Closes a statement (checks for null-value), logs any error as warning using closeLogger.

      • close

        public static void close(ResultSet rs)
        Closes a resultset (checks for null-value), logs any error as warning using closeLogger.

      • preparePlaceHolders

        public static String preparePlaceHolders(int length)
        Utility method for constructing a prepared statement using the 'in' keyword.
        Copied from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/178479/preparedstatement-in-clause-alternatives.
        Usage:
         String SQL_FIND = "SELECT id, name, value FROM data WHERE id IN (%s)" 
 String sql = String.format(SQL_FIND, preparePlaceHolders(ids.size()));
 statement = connection.prepareStatement(sql);
 setValues(statement, ids.toArray());
 resultSet = statement.executeQuery();
        See also setValues(PreparedStatement, Object...).

      • setValues

             Object... values)
                      throws SQLException
        See comments on preparePlaceHolders(int)
        Throws:
        SQLException
